abstracts.cdata!:
The project assessment is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability is uncertain, and, both the
            Bank and Borrower's performances are partially
            satisfactory. The key lessons suggest the need for project
            design to include, not only components which would
            complement the objectives of the project, but that the
            specificity of these objectives, should be clearly defined.
            Needless to say, project input, focussed at the regional
            level, will have a greater impact if national programs
            support regional integration. This further emphasizes the
            need to ensure that project inputs be linked to the
            macroeconomic reality; for, although the project succeeded
            in training women in health care services - following
            studies which conveyed a certain relentlessness in women
            seeking health care (mainly due to the unavailability of
            women health workers) - the fact remains, that recent women
            graduates, have not been able to find employment with the
            public sector. The weak records management, and, lack of
            adequate monitoring and evaluation, indicates how important
            management may prove for the success of an operation, since
            the weak management procedures hindered implementation. An
            effective monitoring and evaluation strategy should be
            defined early on, during project preparation, and its
            evaluation system in place, prior to implementation.

18150946.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18150946.theme: Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Child health

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen Arab Republic - Health Sector
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
In order to facilitate the
            government's efforts to improve health services and to
            expand health care coverage, the project will strengthen the
            administrative, human resources, and support services base
            at the regional level through : 1) development of regional
            administrative capabilities, medical equipment maintenance,
            supplies management, staff training and retraining,
            construction of 9 maintenance workshops for biomedical
            equipment and 9 pharmaceutical storage facilities and
            provision of equipment, materials and furniture; 2) health
            manpower development : construction of 3 regional institutes
            for nursing and midwifery training; provision of training
            materials and equipment, and upgrading of curricula for
            nursing and medical technicians; and 3) development of a
            program to strengthen health care management and hospital administration.

Yemen Arab Republic - Health Sector
            Development Project
